results.content:
Oh man, where to start. I was going to wait until I finished the entire course to write this review. But after completing all of the projects before the 'OLD PROJECTS' section, I felt it's necessary to give some feedback.

I think it's most appropriate to begin by denouncing some negative reviews I've read regarding John's English. If someone truly thinks his English is bad, then I have no idea what kind of English you speak where you are from. The dude is clear, concise, and no one should have any trouble understanding him.

To address another negative review where someone mentioned that John assumes his students know everything nearly made me fall out of my chair. Before each project, the concepts that will be used in that project are broken down and explained at great depth. Even during the project, John reiterates certain things that may have been confusing at their initial introductions. To imply that he doesn't explain the "logic and the need behind every step he took" is a downright lie. If you require more detail than what John provides, you'd be better off taking up knitting or kite flying.

Having said all of this, my appreciation for John amplified to the point where I had to write this review, when I began doing the 'OLD PROJECTS'. Seeing how much this course has evolved makes you realize how much work went into making this. The difference in coding style and efficiency from the new projects versus the old ones is night and day. I'm going to finish them all just for extra practice, but the newer ones are on a completely different level. Thanks for leaving up the old ones for us to get more practice.

I recommend this course to anyone looking to learn HTML & CSS. Thanks John, and I'll see you in your Javascript course!

results.content:
This is an amazing beginner/intermediate course. John's teaching abilities are among the best I have seen. He is well prepared, has the right attitude and his lectures are as explicit as they can be. All subjects are very well covered and what you learn here is enough even to get started with some freelance jobs. Of course, it's impossible to cover everything there is to know about html & css in such a short video course, but John manages to deliver what he has gathered as the most essential, yet important aspects of the subject, sufficient enough for us students to start creating modern/responsive websites right away. I'm very pleased with the course. I don't want to rate it 5 stars, for there is always room for improvement, but this is really a 6 star course (if such a thing is possible).
I own as well his javascript and react courses. I can't wait to start those!
For John: I would love to see a course about css effects and designs. You know, different creative kinds of buttons, transitions, hero presentations as well as creative layouts for the whole page.

results.content: Once again, excellent course by John Smilga. In some ways, I preferred his course on Bootstrap. I think it'd be more suited for beginners, not in the last place because Bootstrap is generally a more beginner-friendly approach to HTML and CSS, but this course was really great as an in-depth refresher. I've been working with CSS and SCSS for a very long time now, but every once in a while it's good to go back to the basics, and you'll find answers to many strange little problems you haven't been able to put your finger on before. Realizing that images are inline, and that a strange margin can appear if you don't specifically set their display to block inside a div was one of those "aha"/facepalm moments I experienced while following this course. And there are many more. The best CSS/HTML course on Udemy in my opinion is still the one by Jonas Schmedtmann, but John definiely delivers quality material with this course. You really can't go wrong.

results.content:
I just finished every single lesson in this course. I definitely recommend it and I would rate it 19/20.

About two years ago I was learning HTML & CSS for the first time in my life in an in-person course at the university. It went really fast and everything was rushed because the curriculum was more inclined towards teaching traditional Back End technologies related to Microsoft and Oracle. We were supposed to have learned HTML & CSS in just two months. The result of this hurry was awful and most of us had to rely exclusively on Bootstrap to try to mock-up websites. I eventually quit that career because I couldn't keep up the pace. I then tried starting from scratch and reviewing HTML & CSS by myself with the help of online documentation and exercises, using platforms such as W3Schools and FreeCodeCamp. I got somewhat better in HTML & CSS, around 25% I would say. But still, I was far from being able to code the mockup of a website on my own. I thought it was exclusively my fault and that I wasn't meant for it. But I didn't give up yet and tried again through Udemy and I enrolled in John Smilga's course.

The first great thing about John's course is that he doesn't rush anything. He takes the amount of time and content that both HTML & CSS deserve. At universities and coding bootcamps these topics are rushed supposedly because of being easy or not as important, and you're just left with an overview. You're able to answer questions and take theoretical exams about it, but you can't actually take on a real project by yourself. In Udemy I learned much more than at university and external documentation platforms together. John takes the time to explain each concept, and also you get to practice most of the concepts over and over again through practical projects. After John's course, I estimate my progress from 25% to around 80%. I must say however that I actually took two Udemy courses on the subject. I made the first half of John's, then went through the other one from start to finish, and finally came back to complete the remaining half.

John's course theoretical part is already pretty good because it's really complete. But the mini-projects and full-projects parts were even better, and those are the ones that really took me from a beginner level to an intermediate-advanced level. I now feel that I can take on a full Home Page project all on my own (regarding HTML & CSS). I have also a good understanding of relative/absolute positioning, flexbox, and grid, which were confusing and daunting topics back when I started. Back when I started this course I felt that the course needed a bit more mini-projects because it jumped right away from theoretical demonstrations to very large projects. However, the addition of the Grid Mini Projects and Additional Projects section was absolutely great. I was able to do understand and code myself about 90% of the additional projects (on average) at the end of the course, needing only to peek at the solution videos for the remaining 10%.

Apart from the very positive project-oriented style by itself. Another very great thing about the course is that John posts the final working website of the projects, which is an absolute great help because it allows you to try the upcoming lectures as challenges and try to do as much as you can yourself before going through the entire lecture without understanding where are we aiming at. It's evident that there is great planning and preparation of projects beforehand from the very start, instead of what some instructors do which is just planning one lecture ahead and bouncing back and forth within the lectures about the content and appearance of the end result.

Yet two other great things about this course are that:1) John is creating new and updated content continuously. When I came back to complete the second half of the course, a lot of it was updated and there were also many new sections, and 2) John is active in the Question & Answers section and he has replied to my questions whenever I posted one.

There's still, however, some content that I believe this course should include and is somehow missing: Yet another simple mini-projects section in the middle of the CSS theoretical chapters (Sections 4 to 14). I believe that there is too much straight time invested in the CSS fundamentals and properties without an actual simple application. And once you finally complete all those sections, the Tea Station project (don't get me wrong, it is an absolutely great project) is still very demanding at that point in the course. The final Additional Projects section is great for students that have gone through all the chapters and know Grid and Flexbox by then, but there should be a simpler Mini-Projects section that should require neither Flexbox nor Grid by the middle of the CSS theoretical chapters, in order to apply and internalize the fundamental CSS properties before facing all of a sudden such a large project as the Tea Station.

Other than that, the structure, pace, content, and projects are absolutely great and I definitely recommend this course. Probably the best HTML & CSS specific course in Udemy considering both content quality and quantity.
results.content_html:
I just finished every single lesson in this course. I definitely recommend it and I would rate it 19/20.

About two years ago I was learning HTML & CSS for the first time in my life in an in-person course at the university. It went really fast and everything was rushed because the curriculum was more inclined towards teaching traditional Back End technologies related to Microsoft and Oracle. We were supposed to have learned HTML & CSS in just two months. The result of this hurry was awful and most of us had to rely exclusively on Bootstrap to try to mock-up websites. I eventually quit that career because I couldn't keep up the pace. I then tried starting from scratch and reviewing HTML & CSS by myself with the help of online documentation and exercises, using platforms such as W3Schools and FreeCodeCamp. I got somewhat better in HTML & CSS, around 25% I would say. But still, I was far from being able to code the mockup of a website on my own. I thought it was exclusively my fault and that I wasn't meant for it. But I didn't give up yet and tried again through Udemy and I enrolled in John Smilga's course.

The first great thing about John's course is that he doesn't rush anything. He takes the amount of time and content that both HTML & CSS deserve. At universities and coding bootcamps these topics are rushed supposedly because of being easy or not as important, and you're just left with an overview. You're able to answer questions and take theoretical exams about it, but you can't actually take on a real project by yourself. In Udemy I learned much more than at university and external documentation platforms together. John takes the time to explain each concept, and also you get to practice most of the concepts over and over again through practical projects. After John's course, I estimate my progress from 25% to around 80%. I must say however that I actually took two Udemy courses on the subject. I made the first half of John's, then went through the other one from start to finish, and finally came back to complete the remaining half.

John's course theoretical part is already pretty good because it's really complete. But the mini-projects and full-projects parts were even better, and those are the ones that really took me from a beginner level to an intermediate-advanced level. I now feel that I can take on a full Home Page project all on my own (regarding HTML & CSS). I have also a good understanding of relative/absolute positioning, flexbox, and grid, which were confusing and daunting topics back when I started. Back when I started this course I felt that the course needed a bit more mini-projects because it jumped right away from theoretical demonstrations to very large projects. However, the addition of the Grid Mini Projects and Additional Projects section was absolutely great. I was able to do understand and code myself about 90% of the additional projects (on average) at the end of the course, needing only to peek at the solution videos for the remaining 10%.

Apart from the very positive project-oriented style by itself. Another very great thing about the course is that John posts the final working website of the projects, which is an absolute great help because it allows you to try the upcoming lectures as challenges and try to do as much as you can yourself before going through the entire lecture without understanding where are we aiming at. It's evident that there is great planning and preparation of projects beforehand from the very start, instead of what some instructors do which is just planning one lecture ahead and bouncing back and forth within the lectures about the content and appearance of the end result.

Yet two other great things about this course are that:1) John is creating new and updated content continuously. When I came back to complete the second half of the course, a lot of it was updated and there were also many new sections, and 2) John is active in the Question & Answers section and he has replied to my questions whenever I posted one.

There's still, however, some content that I believe this course should include and is somehow missing: Yet another simple mini-projects section in the middle of the CSS theoretical chapters (Sections 4 to 14). I believe that there is too much straight time invested in the CSS fundamentals and properties without an actual simple application. And once you finally complete all those sections, the Tea Station project (don't get me wrong, it is an absolutely great project) is still very demanding at that point in the course. The final Additional Projects section is great for students that have gone through all the chapters and know Grid and Flexbox by then, but there should be a simpler Mini-Projects section that should require neither Flexbox nor Grid by the middle of the CSS theoretical chapters, in order to apply and internalize the fundamental CSS properties before facing all of a sudden such a large project as the Tea Station.

Other than that, the structure, pace, content, and projects are absolutely great and I definitely recommend this course. Probably the best HTML & CSS specific course in Udemy considering both content quality and quantity.

results.content: Gefällt mir mittlerweile ganz gut, allerdings sind viele Erklärungen redundant, so werden die Basics und die einfachen logischen Zusammenhänge meist viel zu oft wiederholt (wie u.a. der Hinweis, dass man die Werte nach Belieben abändern kann etc.), wohingegen bei größeren Zusammenhängen oder schwierigeren Themen oftmals auf exemplarische Darstellungen verzichtet wird. Stattdessen wird ein endlos langes Beispiel nach dem anderen durchbesprochen, wo sich sooo viele Dinge immer und immer wieder wiederholen. Hier hätte man sich auf das Wesentliche beschränken können, das würde den Kurs sicher übersichtlicher gestalten. Ziemlich nervig ist, dass der Dozent sich ständig verschreibt und verspricht, und durch Korrekturen sehr viel Zeit draufgeht. Tabellarische Übersichten wären auch sehr hilfreich. Auch ein paar eigene Übungsaufgaben wären sicher toll, sodass man nicht einfach alles vorgebetet bekommt, sondern selbst denken muss, und anschließend wird dann eine Lösung besprochen. Toll sind die Nebentipps, wo und wie man zu entsprechendem Content für Websites kommt, wie Icons, Hintergrundbilder etc. Auch der lockere Stil des Dozenten gestaltet sich als sehr sympathisch. Hab jetzt 60% des Kurses, bin gespannt wie's weiter geht.

results.content: An incredibly thorough introductory course into HTML and CSS.  John explains each topic clearly, and the projects he has created for the course really help with putting together all those topics practically.  Not to mention he also teaches how to setup, and use, many complimentary tools for web development like Visual Studio Code, GitHub, Netlify, Formspree, Font Awesome, etc.  It would have taken me several months to learn what John has managed to teach me in weeks.
